title.narrative: Providing life-sustaining assistance and protection to vulnerable families of Damascus Southern Suburbs

description.narrative: The proposed Action falls within the framework of the relief and protection programme started at the end of 2012 by Armadilla, in close cooperation with the local association Zahret Al Madaen, in favour of conflict-afflicted vulnerable communities of Damascus Southern Suburbs. The Project aims at providing life-sustaining assistance and protection to 620 displaced and host community families in Damascus Southern Suburbs. It meets the humanitarian needs of conflict-affected people who are daily struggling for survival and are not able to satisfy the basic needs, due to their condition of displacement, reduced income and soaring prices. Across the humanitarian intervention, the Project integrates gender, protection mainstreaming and resilience, since it promotes child protection activities through assisting women in fostering resilience processes of their children. The beneficiaries of the Project are 620 of the most vulnerable families attending the ZAM Centre in Midan. Among them, 71% are IDPs, 22% Refugees and 7% Hosting families/poor families attending the Centre activities. The most vulnerable families that will receive assistance by the project, are the ones with a prevalence of children, youngsters or other members of the family with people affected by different disabilities and suffering from chronic diseases. Many families are headed by breadwinners who have lost their jobs or newly widowed women who lost their husbands. The initial conditions of poverty, low income, scarce access to basic services, of these families have been further aggravated by the negative impact of the conflict, as a consequence of displacement, loss of job, increasing prices, human losses. They actually need urgent life-saving support and adequate assistance to prevent the existing vulnerabilities from further deteriorating. Among the different needs arisen during the periodical assessments made by Armadilla and ZAM, the Organisations decide to concentrate the efforts in assistance the families through the distribution of food parcels, considering the high level of food insecurity registered in the zone. Moreover, the project will keep continuing in implementing psychosocial activities with women and girls, considering the high value of those also in terms of cost/effectiveness. In this project, beneficiaries that feel the needs of it, will attend individual sessions with the Armadilla’s Counsellor and group of women/girls will attend specific group sessions for receiving Psychological First-Aid sessions that can be reproduced in the future with other groups. Moreover, the expert conducting the training will choose four persons from the two first groups trained on the PFA under the monitoring of the expert, they that will be able in giving the same training to other groups, in order to replicate at cascade the impact of the activity on more and more women and girls of the community.
